abstract: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing. Except, of course, when it comes to Apple’s own products.
snippet: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing. Except, of course, when it comes to Apple’s own products.
lead_paragraph: Let me get this straight: Steve Jobs insists that songs on iTunes cost 99 cents and television episodes cost $1.99 because consumers crave simple pricing.

abstract: iPhone users have felt the sting of high roaming charges with their devices, and many of them are complaining to the company or on blogs.
snippet: iPhone users have felt the sting of high roaming charges with their devices, and many of them are complaining to the company or on blogs.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 — When Neil Dingman recently went on a European vacation, he took his iPhone with him with no intention of using it much. In fact, for the 14 days he was there, he used it only a handful of times and had expected to see just a small increase in his next bill for roaming charges.

headline.main: Fun, Tours and a $3,000 Bill for Hardly Using an iPhone
headline.print_headline: Fun, Tours and a $3,000 Bill For Hardly Using an iPhone

abstract: Seagate’s chief executive, Bill Watkins, talks about the future of storage and how the company bumbled its attempt to start selling drives to Apple.
snippet: Seagate’s chief executive, Bill Watkins, talks about the future of storage and how the company bumbled its attempt to start selling drives to Apple.
lead_paragraph: Hard-drives are a brutal business. A lot of capital is required to design and build them, yet they are commodities that are often subject to vicious price wars.

headline.main: Seagate: Missed the IPod but Selling to Lots of Snoops

abstract: Apple announces it has sold 1 million iPhones, beating its target by three weeks. Translation: We did NOT cut the price because sales were slow.
snippet: Apple announces it has sold 1 million iPhones, beating its target by three weeks. Translation: We did NOT cut the price because sales were slow.
lead_paragraph: If you needed a sign that Apple, for all its aloofness, wants to fine-tune its public image, look to today’s press release announcing that the company sold its 1 millionth iPhone, achieving its third-quarter goal three weeks early.

headline.main: 1 Million Reasons Not to Be Down on Apple’s Stock
